entry.et: Middle English, from Old English meahte, mihte; akin to Old High German mahta, mohta could

dt.un: used in auxiliary function to express permission, liberty, probability, possibility in the past the president might do nothing without the board's consent or a present condition contrary to fact if you were older you might understand or less probability or possibility than may might get there before it rains or as a polite alternative to may might I ask who is calling or to ought or should you might at least apologize

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English miht; akin to Old High German maht might, magan to be able may

def.dt: :the power, authority, or resources wielded (as by an individual or group)
:the power, energy, or intensity of which one is capable striving with might and main

entry.et: Middle English (1st & 3d singular present indicative), from Old English mæg; akin to Old High German mag (1st & 3d singular present indicative) have power, am able (infinitive magan), and perhaps to Greek mēchos means, expedient

def.dt: :have permission to you may go now :be free to a rug on which children may sprawl C. E. Silberman used nearly interchangeably with can

dt.un: used to indicate possibility or probability you may be right things you may need
sometimes used interchangeably with can one of those slipups that may happen from time to time Jessica Mitford
sometimes used where might would be expected you may think from a little distance that the country was solid woods Robert Frost
used in auxiliary function to express a wish or desire especially in prayer, imprecation, or benediction may the best man win

used in auxiliary function expressing purpose or expectation I laugh that I may not weep or contingency she'll do her duty come what may or concession he may be slow but he is thorough or choice the angler may catch them with a dip net, or he may cast a large, bare treble hook Nelson Bryant

def.dt: :shall must used in law where the sense, purpose, or policy requires this interpretation
